impact.statement: People around the world experience and enjoy a single, unified Web that works consistently across devices, browsers, and platforms, ensuring users can freely choose the tools they want to interact with the Web.

outcomes.statement: Many user agents are available that make meaningfully different choices.

indicators.description: There should be a steady or decreasing rate of features that: 1) only work on 1 implementation. 2) work on some but not all implementations. Measured as a fraction of Baseline features.
The number of browsers that support Baseline, keep up with security patches, and make noticeably different design choices, stays steady or increases.

outcomes.statement: Governments don't restrict access to the Web.

outputs.statement: The W3C helps governments make good decisions.

outcomes.statement: People can choose to use the Web for digital activity

indicators.description: An increasing fraction of people’s time on computers is done on the Web

If a capability is widely adopted on a non-web platform and it doesn’t conflict with the W3C’s ethical principles, the web gets the capability no more than N years after the non-web platform. Failing that, a WG should have developed a specification for the capability, and at least 1 browser should have shipped it. Ideally this spec is at CR or higher
